comments.commentBody:
With apologies to Warren Zevon:

“We confirmed a new Attorney General the way we always do
How were we to know he was with the Russians, too?
We were gambling with our future - we took a little risk
Send articles of impeachment
Dad, get me out of this”

There is nothing in it for the majority party to rush to investigate anything. An intact Trump administration is required in order for Republicans to get the pick of their choice on the Supreme Court. I would expect this to change as soon as Neil Gorsuch is confirmed.
How long will this mentally numb nation sit drooling and doing nothing about a chief federal law enforcement official who is a prima facie perjurer?

"Obama...Rushed to preserve..." - what awkwardness is this?
I came into this article angrily suspecting some kind of spin that was going to attempt to blame Obama, based on that terribly constructed headline.

I don't think they "rushed" - they responded in real time, appropriately.
And they didn't "preserve" - they investigated and publicized, also appropriately.
It should be an interesting day.

Obama Knew About Russia Hack During Election, Hid To Help Hillary
http://www.dailywire.com/news/11634/obama-refused-disclose-russian-hacki...
If there was any evidence, Obama would have leaked it before the election.

I'm sure this basic fact, the act of a Democratic administration preserving important legal information, will be spun as a partisan conspiracy by our current administration and the Republican Congress.

Two things stand out in this story.

The first is the complete and continued dishonesty of the media. It is clear from the full context of the exchange between Sessions and Sen Franken that he was asked about whether he was aware of any contacts that the CAMPAIGN had with Russian officials. He was not asked about whether he personally had contacts with them outside his role in the campaign. So the suggestion that he lied is, well... a lie.

The other takeaway is the completely underhanded manner in which the outgoing Obama administration sought to undermine the incoming Trump administration by seeding unconfirmed rumors throughout the bureaucratic structure.

These, taken together with the active sedition being engaged in by leftist apparatchiks throughout federal bureaucracy, constitute one of the most devious and anti-democratic movements ever taken by one administration against its successor.

This is the story the NYT should be reporting on, rather than fake news about Sessions.

replies.commentBody: Why would Romney be owed an apology?

Romney is owed an apology because during the presidential debates he said that our biggest geopolitical enemy was Russia , and he was laughed at , myself included .
Governor Romney , you were right and we were wrong . Apologies .
Karen M
Springfield , NJ

comments.commentBody:
Given the chance to do it all over again, I would still vote for Obama twice, without question.

That said, I am thinking back to the 2012 Presidential Debates. I think we Democrats/Liberals owe Mitt Romney an apology.
Taking all the extra words out of the article and making it precise,concise and exact the government employees are a criminal gang

replies.commentBody: Clinton is not President and never will be, no matter what happens to Trump.  Her campaign missteps are irrelevant to the current question --  whether our current President has undisclosed debts or alliances with a foreign government.  The American people deserve to know one way or the other, regardless of how or whether they voted. Trump should dispel these worries by releasing his tax returns immediately.

comments.commentBody:
Did the Russians compel Hillary to accept obscene amounts of cash as "speaking fees" from big Wall St banks?

Did the Russians round up all of Hillary's BlackBerry devices and smash them with hammers to avoid congressional inquiry (HOW IS THIS NOT EVER TALKED ABOUT BTW??)

Did the Russians force Hillary to surround herself with the likes of Huma Abedin (she was married to WHOM??) and some old dude that couldn't distinguish GMail from DailyMail, and handed over all their dirty little secrets on a silver platter?

This rabid mission to confront Russia over an alleged plot to foil Hillary is quickly morphing from an annoying sidebar into Benghazi territory.

Trump won the election; get on with the governing now. Us independents, many who have voted Democratic in the past (2x Obama voter here) are ~watching closely~. Continue expending time and effort on this silliness (instead of governing and improving the Democratic party brand) at your own peril.....

Although my heart and mind are with the democratic party I believe that some of its members and some members of the intelligence community need to see a psychologist to determine the origin and fervor of their anti-Russian feelings. As for now I am with  John Mearsheimer 's dictum that there is no hard evidence for the alleged Russian attack on the American democracy. Similar fears that the Russians were undermining the democratic fabric in Germany were put to rest a short while ago by the BND, the national intelligence service of Germany, who had researched for one year in vain to find any convincing clues of such interference.

replies.commentBody:
Judging by what? The relative crowd sizes of the opposition rallies and town halls versus the sad and lonely turnouts at those pro-Trump rallies you tried to muster last week? Please.

You won a very slim Electoral College victory and lost the popular vote by millions. Can you say "emoluments"? I know you can.

comments.commentBody:
After perusing the comments here, I am reassured that the NYT is an extension of the Demoncrat party machine and nothing more. It ceased being a "newspaper" long, long ago.

The demagogues have nothing to cling to but their bitter anger at having been destroyed in the 2016 election. This is their response and it will backfire on them big-time in 2018. The Republicans could very well end up with veto-proof majorities in both houses of Congress, and the demagogues will be delegated to the dustbin of history.
Smart, Obama staffers.  Very smart.
Got a new hashtag for AG Jeff Sessions, though I had to sanitize it a bit for the comment section.   #BS_Sessions
It sounds as if Sessions perjured himself. Why not obtain and publish opinions from former Democratic and Republican AGs on that subject?
Let's circle back and remember how this absurd farce began:  with Hillary Clinton maintaining a private e mail server and then being less than truthful about it.

Well, as I was about to comment, I realized the last guy said the same thing. Bears repeating, though.  It is a shame and national disgrace when a candidate, now president, is so vile and corrupt that responsible government sources have to go to these lengths to preserve history.  As for Sessions, who'll probably end up "investigating" - sure, we know where that's headed - this matter, since the story was printed, he has now admitted meeting with the Russian ambassador, but says he didn't consider it important enough to mention during the confirmation hearings.  And he really didn't remember it anyway.  Right.  You meet with a foreign ambassador and don't remember it?  Do we have an attorney general with Alzheimer's disease maybe?

replies.commentBody: You should've stopped at "most Americans don't care", because then you would've been right.

comments.commentBody: how desperate has the left become to continue to talk about this nonsense. most Americans don't care. They care about jobs, health care, their lives. They don't want to entertain the left's fallacies to somehow regain some footing after a failed Hillary election and failed Obama presidency.

Elections have consequences.  The Russians won the Presidency, the House and the Senate.  There will be no special prosecutor, no demand for tax returns and no real investigation.  Hopefully the Germans or Sweden will take back our government in the next election.

replies.commentBody:
No, I think the general consensus is (and this is also coming from Republicans as well, at this point), we need to know more, and they're not being particularly forthcoming.

Take Sessions' statement: he didn't speak with the Russian ambassador about any campaign. OK, what did you talk about, and explain how it was relevant to your job as a Senator. Or is it that you didn't speak about "the campaign", but you were discussing some other matter that was still important to Trump's businesses, which would have *absolutely nothing* to do with your responsibilities as a Senator? We need to know more before dismissing this as "nothing to see here".

I can't believe this guy is the "top cop" of the country. Coretta Scott King was right.

comments.commentBody:
No liberal pimping in this article. Cudos NYT. This, I think, is what the Founders had in mind when they proposed a free press, an informed electorate etc. Necessary, but hard to read for a committed conservative like me! (A few more "just-the-facts-maam" articles like this one and some of your readership, prodigals though we may be, might just return to the fold!).

But let's be careful. No American should ever be required to prove that he or she has "nothing to hide." That itself, is a crime. If the FBI investigation or the House or Senate committee investigations produce probable cause that crimes have been committed, let's prosecute and, if necessary, designate a special prosecutor. But let's not confuse Russian crimes with administration crimes, if any. The central issue seems to be, that it is NOT illegal for Trump campaign members to speak to any foreign ambassador, Russian or otherwise. And, that it IS illegal to conduct government business in those conversations as a non-government employee (eg., Flynn but not Sessions) and certainly illegal to collude with a foreign nation to influence any American election, government employee or not.

At this point, our intelligence community says there is no such evidence. So Ms. Pelosi et al, your Resist Now, Resign Now, Impeach Now message could be construed as an abuse of free speech, which is to say free cowspit.

replies.commentBody: Sessions meeting occurred 3 days after President Obama met with Putin at the G20 summit.

comments.commentBody:
In the 1970s and 80s western officials, politicians, etc. would generally bring a note-taker to meetings with Soviet and Eastern Block officials and ambassadors, especially closed door meetings (as opposed to open social encounters), in part to avoid kompromat. Senators routinely bring staffers as note-takers into meetings with lobbyists, especially foreign lobbyists. Sessions met with Sergey Kislyak in Session’s office?  Was it a closed door meeting?  How was it set up? Did Sessions meet alone? If he met a member of Armed Services Committee, it would be normal and appropriate to have a note-taker.

The Justice department tries to defend this by saying that in addition to the Russian diplomat, Sessions met the British, South Korean, Japanese, Chinese and German ambassadors. But under what circumstances? In his office, without a notetaker or a social encounter? There is a big difference between the British and German ambassadors, both NATO allies; South Korea and Japan are also allies with a sizeable US military presence in their countries - a good justification for a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee to have a meeting. The Russian is a representative of a government with difficult relations with the US (e.g., Syria, Ukraine) that at the time of the meeting was suspected of inappropriately trying to influence the US election, in favour of someone who Sessions was known to be a proxy for?

Sessions has questions to answer yet.

A disgraceful article worthy of Pravda. All this happened when Obama was POTUS. If half of this is true it is the Obama administration that needs to be investigated because it was his administration that failed to protect our electoral process.

And of course, Putin is such a genius that he foresaw that the election would be close even though American pundits (including the geniuses at the NYT) were predicting an easy victory for Clinton.

Regarding AG* Jeff Sessions, it's a simple equation:

Perjury + Logan Act = Resignation and charges.

His deputy-by-executive-order needs to also be questioned. Where there's smoke, there's fire.

Donny, you're out of your element!

Now about the secret private server in Trump Tower and its direct communications with Russia's Alfa group....
http://www.salon.com/2016/11/01/donald-trump-companys-server-was-connect...

Pro-Russian plank inserted into the Republican Party platform...
http://www.npr.org/2016/08/06/488876597/how-the-trump-campaign-weakened-...

Trump tax returns....

Paul Manafort, Carter Page, Michael Flynn, others...

The former MI6 spy Steele dossier...

Republican refusal to investigate...

Connect the dots....

We need a fully funded and fully staffed independent counsel to investigate and expose the truth. The national security of the United States and its allies is at risk.
